session_summary.goal: Build MI-V Triple Modular Redundancy (TMR) system for high-reliability applications - FULL IMPLEMENTATION

achievements: ✅ Phase 1: Complete TMR architecture design (650-line document)

key_decisions: Focused demo on TMR system vs simple LED blink (FAE-level complexity)
Full system TMR: 3x cores + 3x memory + 3x peripherals + voting
Use Microchip IP cores wherever possible (not custom Verilog)
Voting at memory/IO interface (practical vs instruction-level)
Target: MPF300TS eval kit (plenty of resources for 3x MI-V)
Simplified SmartDesign for initial build (voter integration documented for Phase 2)
pending_tasks: Run synthesis + place & route (50-75 min estimated)
Analyze resource utilization and timing results

miv_tmr_project.goal: High-reliability RISC-V processor system with Triple Modular Redundancy
miv_tmr_project.complexity: Production-level TMR system (not a toy demo)

architecture.peripherals: 3x UART + 3x GPIO + 3x Timer (all using IP cores)
architecture.voting: Memory address, memory data, peripheral outputs
architecture.fault_detection: Per-core fault counters, persistent fault flags
architecture.synchronization: Synchronized reset distribution to all cores

constraints: constraint/tmr/miv_tmr_io.pdc (pin assignments for MPF300 eval kit)

resource_estimate.verdict: Fits comfortably in MPF300TS (299k LUTs available)

demo_value.time_savings: 1-2 weeks manual → 3 hours with AI assistance

demo_value.differentiator: Not LED blink - actual high-reliability system

what_works: All IP cores configured (using Microchip cores)
phase_2_enhancements: Fault monitor connection to status register
Software test program (firmware for MI-V cores)
lessons_learned: Use IP cores first - only write Verilog when no IP exists
TMR voting at interface level is practical (vs instruction-level)
Simplified initial build validates architecture before full integration
Real FAE work requires production-level complexity demos

beaglev_fire_work.status: ✅ Phase 1 Complete - Ready for Phase 2 Integration
beaglev_fire_work.project_goal: Modify/extend BeagleV-Fire reference design with custom MSS, FPGA fabric, and cape connectors

beaglev_fire_demo.status: Fresh/empty - no HDL or constraints yet

device_info.peripherals: 2x GigE, USB 2.0, 5x UART, 2x SPI, 2x I2C, 2x CAN, 2x PCIe Gen2

build_configurations: default - Full design with cape + M.2 Wi-Fi
minimal - Linux only, no FPGA fabric
phase_1_tasks_completed: ✅ Explored BeagleV-Fire files and understood structure (3 resources identified)
✅ Read and analyzed key reference TCL scripts (BUILD_BVF_GATEWARE, generate-project, import-clients, run-flow)
✅ Analyzed Python builder workflow and requirements
✅ Created design variants configuration (config/beaglev_fire_variants.json with 8 variants)
✅ Updated PROJECT_STATE.json with all Phase 1 findings
phase_1_key_insights: BUILD_BVF_GATEWARE.tcl uses modular component architecture (CAPE, M2, APU, SYZYGY, MIPI_CSI)
Parameter-driven configuration via TCL arguments (CAPE_OPTION:ROBOTICS syntax)
Three-stage build flow pattern: generate-project → import-clients → run-flow
Python builder combines HSS bootloader + FPGA bitstream (heavyweight approach)
Opportunity for lightweight TCL-only build flow without Python dependencies
Constraint organization is modular - each component has its own PDC/SDC files
MSS configuration stored in mss.bundle (git bundle format)
Multi-pass P&R strategy for timing closure (MAX delay → incremental MIN delay)

token_savings.rationale: Comprehensive documentation eliminates need to re-explore reference design

beaglev_fire_work.next_action: Phase 2 - Extract reference components and create tcl_monster integration scripts

tftp_server.purpose: File transfer to BeagleV-Fire (alternative to scp)

context_management.recommendation: Compact now - session complete, ready for next phase
context_management.reason: LED blink workflow complete and documented, ready to resume with fresh context

key_learnings: MI-V + DDR4 is more complex than expected without proper app note
Official MI-V reference uses SRAM, not DDR
Always verify app note covers exact use case before committing time
For demos: working design > perfect design
.mcp.json is ONLY for MCP server configuration - use PROJECT_STATE.json for session state
Memory MCP has ~7k token overhead - only enable for cross-project work
Official Memory MCP server exists and works (entities/relations/observations)
Project-scoped MCP config auto-enables when cd to directory (~/meta-project pattern)
Libero's check_tool command is too strict - use catch {} to allow warnings
PDC files are for pin constraints only - timing goes in SDC files
scp works better than TFTP for file transfer to BeagleV-Fire (simpler setup)
Serial command queue system works well for autonomous board interaction
